paragraphs.text: The State ofAcute Malnutrition

Welcome to the State of Acute Malnutrition newsletter. We've been very busy in the last couple of months gathering and curating available resources related to severe and moderate wasting. In this edition, we're highlighting the latest improvements to our space onInnovations and COVID-19 Adaptations in the Management of Child Wasting. Scroll down for more.

VOICES FROM THE FIELDToday, we're releasing a blog on therisk of SAM relapse for children who are discharged as curedfrom the outpatient therapeutic programme on ournew blog space. Have you read the interview with two medical professionals aboutsuccesses and challenges of implementing Family MUACin the southeast of Niger?

STATE OF ACUTE MALNUTRITION WEBINAR SERIESWe kicked off our new webinar series with two events in October. If you missed them, you can find the recordings for webinar on cost-efficiency and cost effectiveness of interventions to treat wastinghere, and for the second one exploring the potential of scaling up the Family MUAC approach and its feasibility and adaptations in different contexts, including during COVID-19here.
►Block your calendars on 3 December between 1-2:30 pm (London time), and join us for our next webinar oncoverage assessment methodologies.

WHAT'S MORE?Our Communities of Practice keep growing, and we've just added a new page to our Family MUAC CoP highlighting Action for Development's project totrain caregivers and female CHWs in Family MUAC in Afghanistan. More updates on the site are coming soon, with more opportunities to give a platform to frontline workers through webinars and blog posts as well as a members' forum.

Are you looking for wasting specific information, guidance, and tools for the COVID-19 response? Visit theCOVID-19 Adaptations page, which tracks protocol adaptations across contexts, and highlightsinnovative case studiesfrom Ethiopia, Kenya, Somalia, Tanzania, and Uganda.
Click here to explore the COVID-19 Adaptations page.

The page aggregates availabletools, guidance, and other resourceson acute malnutrition treatment in the context of Covid. The top two most reported detection and treatment protocol adaptations are Family MUAC and a modified frequency of follow-up appointments.

NEW RESEARCH AND RESOURCESO. Adegoke et al.,Incidence of severe acute malnutrition after treatment: A prospective matched cohort study in Sokoto, Nigeria, 2020
This study shows that children discharged as cured from SAM at outpatient therapeutic programmes (OTP) remain at a significantly excess risk of SAM. To improve long-term health outcomes of these children, programmes adopting a CMAM approach should strengthen follow-up care and be integrated with other preventive services.
►Read our latest blog postby Julia Hug "Why We Should Care About Relapse Into SAM in Northern Nigeria (and beyond)"

ENN,Field Exchange 63: Child Wasting in South Asia, 2020
The 63rd edition of Field Exchange focuses on child wasting in South Asia. The idea for this issue came out of a meeting in New York in 2018, convened by the UNICEF ROSA team who were feeling somewhat frustrated by the lack of attention and investment in wasting management – especially treatment – in the region. To ‘right this wrong’, ENN and the UNICEF ROSA team launched this issue to give a greater voice to those working in the region.

N. Lelijveld et al.,Long-term outcomes for children with disability and severe acute malnutrition in Malawi, 2020
This longitudinal cohort study in Malawi found that disability is common among children affected by SAM. The authors conclude that, to help children survive and thrive post-SAM, it is vital that those with underlying disability are identified and supported. SAM treatment programmes should consider using more structured assessments, such as screening tools, to better understand the population of children they are serving: clinical assessment alone is likely to be inadequate.

R. Schaefer et al.,Relapse and regression to severe wasting in children under 5 years: A theoretical framework, 2020 
This theoretical framework of post-treatment relapse and regression to severe wasting aims to guide discussions, risk factor analyses, and development and evaluations of interventions. The authors conclude that implementation research is needed to operationalise results in programmes and reduce post-treatment severe wasting at scale.

J. Teague (Bread for the World Institute),Key Ingredients for Faster Progress on Nutrition - Briefing Paper, 2020 
Before the COVID-19 pandemic, global levels of child malnutrition had been decreasing. Yet progress had not been fast enough, because good nutrition is essential to human life, health, and well-being. This paper examines common elements among low- and middle-income countries that have made more progress on nutrition than many of their peer countries

UNICEF,Treatment of Wasting using Simplified Approaches. A Rapid Evidence Review, 2020
The objective of the simplified approaches is to improve the provision of care for wasted children so that barriers to access and uptake of quality services can be effectively and sustainably addressed by health systems around the world. This rapid review aims to provide an overview of the current evidence and practice on the treatment of acute malnutrition using simplified approaches. This review compiles evidence related to simplified approaches for the treatment of wasting and provides a synthesis of the variety of protocols.
► To find out more about Simplified Approaches, visitour Community of Practice.

WFP,Additional Recommendations for the Management of Maternal and Child Malnutrition Prevention and Treatment in the Context of COVID 19, 2020
This brief has been developed to prevent COVID-19 contamination during the provision of acute malnutrition prevention and treatment services at health facility and community level. The aim is to ensure the continuity of provision of acute malnutrition prevention and treatment of services, introducing adaptations where indicated. It highlights the essential minimum adaptations (section 4) needed in all programs that are currently running to ensure safe delivery of services in the context of COVID-19.

Between 2015 and 2020, The State of Acute Malnutrition was supported by theNo Wasted LivesCoalition, an interagency effort between Action Against Hunger, the Children’s Investment Fund Foundation, the European Commission Directorate-General for Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection (ECHO), the innocent foundation, the International Rescue Committee (IRC), UNICEF, and World Food Programme (WFP). The CMAM 2.0: Reinventing Community Management of Acute Malnutrition grant supported by the Children’s Investment Fund Foundation that financed the No Wasted Lives initiative, is now closed.
